Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 43129  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka:
 
Umbrella Technical Assistance Capacity 
Development Fund  
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 27 November 2009) 
 
Currency Unit –  Sri Lanka rupee/s (SLRe/SLRs) 
SLRe1.00 =  $0.01 
$1.00 =  SLRs115.29 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BPPQs  –  best practices, procedures, and guidelines 
  CDF  –  Capacity Development Fund 
  CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
  MOFP  –  Ministry of Finance and Planning 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public sector management (public administration) 
Themes (Subthemes)  –  Governance (public administration); capacity development 
(institutional development); economic growth (promoting economic 
efficiency and enabling business environment)  
Location impact  –  National (high) 
 
 
NOTE   
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  R. Vokes, Sri Lanka Resident Mission (SLRM), SARD 
   
Team leader  N. Rao, Lead Economist, SLRM, SARD 
Team members  H. Fernando, Governance Specialist, SLRM, SARD 
  H. Wickremasinghe, Economics Officer, SLRM, SARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In line with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Second Governance and Anti-Corruption 
Action Plan, the country partnership strategy (CPS) focuses on (i) improving the efficiency and 
transparency of ADB-related procurement, (ii) strengthening and streamlining public financial 
management, and (iii) piloting an innovative approach to capacity development. To strengthen 
the plan in Sri Lanka, the Capacity Development Fund (CDF) will be set up as an umbrella fund. 
Funds will be channeled from the CDF for innovative capacity development initiatives1.  
 
2.  The Government of Sri Lanka identifies in its 10-year development strategy framework 
limited capacity as a key constraint to more effective development and public sector service 
delivery. The guiding principles of the technical assistance (TA) are based on the key findings 
and  recommendations  of  an  ADB  report  titled  Capacity  Development  in  South  Asia.2  In 
preparing the proposed technical assistance, officials and representatives of the Public Service 
Commission (an independent authority for public sector recruitment), National Administrative 
Reforms Council, Department of External Resources, Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP), 
Postgraduate  Institute  for  Management  of  the  University  of  Sri  Jayewardenepura  were 
consulted.  This  was  preceded  by  a  consultative  workshop  held  in  May  2008  with  the 
participation of the Ministries of Finance and Planning, Plan Implementation, Power and Energy, 
Public Administration, Highways, and Water Resources, as well as the Road Development 
Authority, Ceylon Electricity Board, National Water Supply and Drainage Board, and National 
Administrative Reforms Council. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In the consultations leading to the CPS, capacity development was identified as needing 
urgent and focused assistance. ADB already provides capacity development linked to projects 
financed by it to improve the capacity of sector-specific institutions in ADB priority sectors in Sri 
Lanka. However, minimal assistance is currently dedicated to standalone capacity development 
initiatives for cross-cutting institutions and systems such as the Public Service Commission. 
Such institutions have not benefited through ADB project funding.  
 
4.  Capacity development initiatives for the public sector in Sri Lanka are limited and carried 
out by a few state institutions such as the Sri Lanka Institute for Development Administration. 
Dedicated funding for institution-specific capacity development initiatives is limited, resulting in 
low institution-based strategic human resource development. As public employees do not have 
a culture of continuous capacity development, a strong incentive is necessary to introduce 
innovative institution-based capacity development initiatives that are linked to the mandate and 
operational aspects of the institution. Limited allocations for public sector human resources 
development  is  thinly  spread  across  the  country’s  large  public  sector.  In  instances  where 
external funding is available, the perception is that the intervention is driven by donor priorities 
and not necessarily based on local needs. As a result, the effectiveness and sustainability of 
initiatives are poor for lack of beneficiary ownership. State agencies continue to make various 
formal and informal requests in an ad hoc manner for capacity development. Dedicated funding 
in the form of a CDF would enable those agencies to look at institutional human resources 
development in a more sustainable and strategic manner. 
                                                 
1 The Technical Assistance will be listed on Asian Development Bank Business Opportunities in January 2010. 
2 ADB. 2007. Capacity Development in South Asia. ADB Occasional Paper Series No. 1. Manila

2   
 
5.  The drain of human resources from the state institutions experienced in Sri Lanka, which 
has added to the problem of low capacity, occurs (i) from the public sector to the private sector 
as people search for better prospects, and (ii) from Sri Lanka to other countries. Provincial 
capacity  development  is  also  weak  and  needs  strengthening  to  undertake  devolved 
administrative  functions  under  existing  constitutional  provisions.  Innovative  capacity 
development initiatives will provide training to existing public officials and be an incentive to 
retain motivated and talented officials. The CDF will be designed so that the target groups are 
objectively selected based on their ability and continuity in the sector, as well as the direct 
relevance of the intervention to their official powers and functions, thereby minimizing migration 
from public sector institutions benefiting from the CDF. 
 
6.  Capacity improvement is needed throughout the public sector. High-end tasks such as 
strategic policy formulation and the implementation of highly technical and specialized programs 
is often carried out by people outside the core public service, whose services are retained 
mostly project by project. Their experience is therefore not retained in the institution. On several 
occasions,  the  idea  of  establishing  human  resources  cells  in  each  department  has  been 
considered, but it has yet to be implemented. 
 
7.  The CDF will focus attention on capacity issues in the public sector. Funding, though 
relatively  small,  has  potential  for  high  impact  if  used  strategically  and  in  an  institutionally 
focused manner. Proposals for intervention will be evaluated against predetermined criteria that 
bring in international best practices contextualized to suit local conditions and needs. In deciding 
beneficiary institutions, priority will go to those that do not receive direct ADB funding through 
either existing or future projects. The proposed technical assistance will have a discernible 
impact on national capacity development in three principle ways: (i) developing and publishing 
criteria based on international best practices to be used to evaluate and select the most suitable 
proposals, (ii) strongly influencing organizations that compete for funding to generate proposals 
that are innovative and of a high standard, and (iii) funding in phase 1 innovative capacity 
development interventions in respect of  3–5 selected institutions, which then can be studied by 
the government and its development partners as pilots for formulating a broader strategy. 
Institutions with mandates related to capacity development or human resource development 
such as the Public Service Commission can be prioritized for funding out of the CDF, so that 
improvements in them have a catalytic effect on improvement in other institutions.     
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The TA will set up the CDF, which will provide financing for small and medium-scale 
standalone projects that seek to build capacity in state institutions and, to limited extent, national 
and provincial institutions. The CDF initiative will have two phases, with $1.5 million available for 
phase 1. Depending on progress, ADB will decide in consultation with the government on 
making available a further $2 million in 2011. Subject to progress in implementation, additional 
funding also will be provided by other development partners. In phase 1, the CDF is expected to 
develop  the  criteria  for  evaluating  proposals  and  then  fund  3–5  capacity  development 
interventions. An assessment at the end of phase 1 and warranted amendments to operational 
details will be made prior to commencing phase 2. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA impact will be improvement in efficiency and effectiveness in service delivery by 
beneficiary  organizations.  The  envisaged  principal  outcome  of  the  technical  assistance  is

3
increased  institutional  capacity  for  better  service  delivery.    Enhanced  capacity  in  selected 
institutions will contribute to improved public administration and governance through better 
efficiency, service delivery, management of resources and finances, and budget utilization, as 
well as process reengineering and the development of skills in areas such as strategic thinking 
and leadership. The TA is designed to encourage innovation in capacity development and 
generate new ideas by developing a country-specific set of criteria for evaluating innovative 
strategies for capacity development. In addition, the TA will track the number of women direct 
beneficiaries and encourage capacity development initiatives that address gender issues in 
institutions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outputs of the CDF will be 
(i)  the development of best practices and criteria for capacity development initiatives 
that will be published and used to evaluate proposals; 
(ii)  the encouragement of competition for funding and, through it, innovation in public 
sector capacity development; and  
(iii)  the identification, selection, refinement, and funding of capacity development 
initiatives that contribute to better governance. 
  
11.  The  CDF  will  develop  criteria  for  assessing  each  proposal.  It  will  specify  which 
categories of institutions will be eligible for funding. The criteria will be published to set broad 
parameters and infuse international best practice into capacity development in the country. The 
CDF will make available funding for consultant support in assessing capacity needs, developing 
criteria, guiding the development of proposals, and assisting in refining proposals. The criteria 
will be contextual and reflect the following principles: 
(i)  The capacity development intervention addresses well-identified capacity gaps. 
(ii)  It demonstrates strong local ownership. 
(iii)  It  has  clearly  identified  and  well-illustrated  positive  incentives  to  ensure 
beneficiary acceptance and sustainability. 
(iv)  It makes use of existing capacity, and external inputs are integrated with local 
priorities, processes, and systems. 
(v)  Blueprints are avoided, and imported models are suitably amended to suit local 
requirements and conditions. 
(vi)  The intervention is proposed and promoted by individuals and institutions that 
can be categorized as prime movers or drivers of change. 
(vii)  The  target  group  is  objectively  selected  based  on  individuals’  ability  and 
continuity in the sector, as well as the direct relevance of the intervention to their 
official functions. 
(viii)  The intervention promotes transparency, stakeholder participation, inclusiveness, 
and accountability, particularly to the ultimate beneficiaries.3  
(ix)  It deals with gender imbalances in institutions. 
(x)  It incorporates conflict sensitivity training, particularly in capacity development 
interventions targeting institutions that work at the grassroots and in lagging 
regions.  
 
                                                 
3
  Based on good capacity development practices contained in ADB. 2007. Capacity Development in South Asia. 
ADB Occasional Paper Series No. 1. Manila

4   
12.  The CDF will create competition among institutions for funding and encourage local 
public institutions to propose their own strategies for capacity development within the broad 
framework and criteria developed by the CDF. It will provide an avenue for infusing new ideas 
and  best  practices  into  public  sector  capacity  development  through  competition  and  by 
encouraging not only proposals from state institutions but also proposals jointly developed with 
private institutions with proven capability in human resource development. The CDF will make 
available funding for recruiting consultants identified by institutions as necessary to refine and 
implement their proposal once it is selected. Central and provincial institutions are eligible to 
receive funds.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The cost of the technical assistance (TA) is estimated at $1.65 million equivalent. ADB 
will provide $1.5 million equivalent as a grant from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 
–IV). The government will finance the remaining $150,000 equivalent by providing technical and 
logistical support. ADB Sri Lanka Resident Mission will engage other developmental partners for 
parallel cofinancing.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The CDF will be jointly administered by the MOFP and the Sri Lanka Resident Mission. 
The MOFP will be the designated executing agency. Proposals for funding will be approved by a 
steering committee consisting of the secretary of the MOFP as chair, the secretary of the 
Ministry of Public Administration, and the country director of the mission. Proposals will be pre-
evaluated by a technical committee with representatives of the Department of National Planning, 
the mission, and the Administrative Reforms Division of the Ministry of Public Administration, as 
well as a senior representative of the relevant line ministry in the case of department specific 
proposals. Administrative support for the functioning of these committees will be provided by the 
MOFP. The MOFP and ADB will each designate one officer as a principle contact point for this 
TA. The implementing agency of capacity development interventions will be the state entity 
specific to the selected proposal. The MOFP, as the principal contact point for ADB in its 
operations in Sri Lanka, has long experience in project implementation and management, is 
conversant with ADB guidelines and procedures, and has implemented ADB-funded projects in 
the past, including TA, with strong accountability and transparency. 
  
15.  As beneficiary institutions are not expected to have the means to finance the projects 
from their own funds, advance payments will be necessary. ADB will provide an advance to the 
MOFP through an advance payment facility in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.4 The MOFP will provide advances in turn to beneficiary institutions 
and be responsible for liquidating the advance. Successive advances will be made by ADB only 
after liquidation of the prior advances. ADB will assess the capacity of the MOFP for liquidation 
prior to disbursing advances.  
 
16.  Each selected proposal will have a monitoring and evaluation framework with clear 
outputs and outcomes that is acceptable to ADB and in line with the published criteria of the 
CDF. The implementation of projects funded by the CDF will be monitored regularly to ensure 
that progress is in line with the original design and that intended outputs and outcomes are 
being met.  
 
                                                 
4 ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

5
17.  The CDF will require consultancy support at two stages: (i) to develop the guidelines for 
evaluating capacity development proposals and provide assistance to the steering committee in 
applying  the  guidelines  and  (ii)  to  support  beneficiary  institutions’  refinement  and  further 
development  of  their  proposals.  It  is  envisaged  that  the  services  of  two  consultants,  one 
international  and  one  national,  will  be  required  to  develop  the  criteria.  The  international 
consultant will be engaged for 1 person-month and the local consultant for 24 person-months. 
Both consultants will be required to have expertise in human resource development in the public 
sector and experience in implementing capacity development programs. The national consultant 
will need a sound knowledge of public sector administrative processes. Additional consultancy 
services will be procured as necessary for selected proposals, one consultant for each. The 
expertise  required  of  these  consultants  will  depend  on  the  type  of  proposal.  The  national 
consultant will oversee the implementation of the TA for the entire period of its implementation. 
SLRM will be responsible for the recruitment of all consultants as required for the TA and 
subprojects in line with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time), with 10%–15% of the consultancy cost for the international consultant. The TA will 
commence in January 2010 and be implemented for 2 years. Disbursements under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (footnote 3). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for the Umbrella Technical Assistance Capacity Development 
Fund, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultant (1 person-month) 
 
1.  One international consultant will be engaged to develop selection criteria. The consultant 
will support the evaluation of proposals against the criteria by sensitizing the steering committee 
and  developing  general  guidelines  for  potential  beneficiaries  on  the  development  of  their 
proposals. Responsibilities under the technical assistant (TA) will include but not be limited to 
the following: 
(i)  Conduct a survey of literature on capacity development initiatives in South Asia 
and countries similar to Sri Lanka, specifically looking at Asian Development 
Bank documentation, and develop criteria for selecting proposals for funding. 
(ii)  Develop guidelines for beneficiary organizations on proposal application. 
(iii)  Sensitize  the  steering  and  technical  evaluation  committees  on  the  proper 
evaluation of proposals against criteria. 
 
2.   The following outputs will be expected from the consultant: 
(i)  a set of criteria for selecting proposals for funding, 
(ii)  guidelines for potential beneficiaries developing proposals, and 
(iii)  a clear understanding on the part of the steering committee of applying the 
criteria to select proposals for funding 
 
B.  National Consultant (24 person-months) 
3.  One national consultant will be engaged to develop the selection criteria and oversee the 
administration of the TA during the entire implementation period. The consultant will support the 
evaluation of proposals against the criteria by sensitizing the steering committee and developing 
general guidelines for potential beneficiaries on the development of their proposals. 
  
4.   Responsibilities under the TA will include but not be limited to the following:  
(i)  Develop guidelines for beneficiary organizations on making applications for their 
proposals. 
(ii)  Sensitize the steering committee on the proper evaluation of proposals against 
selection criteria. 
(iii)  Administer the TA in close collaboration with the Sri Lanka Resident Mission and 
the Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP), including facilitating the setting up 
of the steering and technical evaluation committees, ensuring that the necessary 
meetings  are  conducted  regularly,  assisting  identified  state  agencies  as 
requested by the steering committee in developing project proposals, supporting 
the  procurement  of  local  consultants  for  further  refining  and  implementing 
proposals, supporting the mission in assessing the capacity of the MOFP prior to 
disbursing  advances,  monitoring  the  liquidation  of  advances  by  the  MOFP, 
organizing workshops, monitoring the progress of selected subprojects and the 
TA overall, and reporting on progress to the steering committee and the mission 
at regular intervals.  
 
5.   The following outputs will be expected from the work of the consultant: 
(i)  a set of criteria against which to select proposals for funding, 
(ii)  guidelines for potential beneficiaries for developing proposals, 
(iii)  a clear understanding on the part of the steering committee on applying the 
criteria to select proposals for funding,

Appendix 3  11
(iv)  three workshops conducted for potential beneficiaries, 
(v)  local consultants procured as needed by the beneficiary institutions, 
(vi)  regular meetings of the steering committee, 
(vii)  quarterly reports on progress, and  
(viii)  a final report at the end of the TA.
